17:02 • 7 days ago

Entrust

Four considerations when selecting as-a-Service Hardware Security Module solutions to secure your encryption keys

Keeping up with the latest security challenges can feel like you are running a race... The post Four considerations when selecting as-a-Service Hardware Security Module solutions to secure your encryption keys appeared first on Entrust Blog.

Keeping up with the latest security challenges can feel like you are running a race that has endless hurdles. From rapid advancements in technology ‚Äì rendering old hardware obsolete ‚Äì to increasingly stringent requirements and regulations, the time and costs can quickly become enormous.

Many of these challenges are related to the migration of compute, storage, and backup services to cloud services. Picture this, you have moved your databases to the cloud. But are you in control of your encryption keys? Do you know who has a copy or could access a copy?

Today‚Äôs solutions offer your organization a choice of how to most effectively secure your encryption keys. You can select a solution that allows your organization to secure your keys in an on-premise HSM or one that allows your organization to protect your keys via a secure connection to a cloud-based HSM with an HSM-as-a-Service (HSMaaS) offering such as Entrust‚Äôs nShield-as-a-Service solution.

Entrust recently partnered with TechValidate to conduct a survey to understand how companies view and are implementing HSMaaS solutions.

From On-Premise to the Cloud

For years, the best practice was to use an HSM deployed on-premise. Concerns about security of software based key storage, separation of keys, and sovereignty requirements made it the only viable option. Over time, as-a-service HSM offerings appeared in the market offering lower costs, and a level of security comparable to on-premise HSMs, with more flexibility and quicker implementation.

The Survey Says

Today‚Äôs organizations are looking to save time and money. The survey showed that 57% of organizations said a key reason for considering subscribing to an HSMaaS offering is to reduce IT management costs. Further, 69% of respondents said that their organizations would realize reduced spend on physical infrastructure. The next closest benefit noted was improved efficiency with 46% of the respondents selecting that benefit.

The focus on saving time and reducing expenses has also been a significant driver of cloud adoption. With the rise of cloud service providers, as-a-service-HSM offerings evolved even further. Leading cloud service providers offer their own unique approach to securing your encryption keys. While these offerings provide convenience and cost-effective solutions, they do not always meet internal security requirements set by some organizations adding further to the complexity involved when deciding how to store your encryption keys.

In addition to saving time and money, HSMaaS solutions like Entrust nShield-as-a-Service provide the same level of support for a wide range of applications. This is something that was also reflected in the survey results. Respondents indicated that once onboarded, they would leverage an HSMaaS solution for a variety of functions.

The top functions ranked were public key infrastructure (PKI), which was mentioned by 60% of respondents followed by key management which was selected by 57% of respondents. Data encryption/decryption and digital signatures were also mentioned by nearly half of the respondents (49%). These results reinforce the similarities in functionality between on-premise HSM and HSMaaS offerings.

Important Cloud Key Management Considerations

Saving time and money are necessary criteria when considering implementing an HSMaaS solution. However, they are not the only considerations you should have when deciding what as-a-service HSM offering to use when storing your encryption keys. It is important to also consider:

Security ‚Äì Make sure you understand how the HSMaaS offering works. Are you sharing the cloud-based HSM with other users or is it for your exclusive use? This is often referred to as single-tenancy vs multi-tenancy. You must ensure that you chose the right solution to match your risk profile and requirements. Sovereignty of keys. Can the HSMaaS provider guarantee what country or region your keys will physically stored in? Will you be compliant with the regulations affecting your organization? Integrations and the compatibility of the key management software with other vendors. Does it integrate with the other products and services used by your organization? Ease of comprehensive key management for the entire organization. Does the solution give you the ability to rotate, generate, discard, and easily access information required during an audit?

Conclusion

When evaluating these considerations and HSMaaS solutions, partnering with a company that understands your holistic security and encryption needs will simplify this process. While cost is always a driving factor, ensuring you are in control of your keys is the most important. Ensuring where your keys are stored for key sovereignty requirements, the available integrations and the key management capabilities need to be carefully reviewed. The right keys need to be stored in the right places, using a solution that will protect your business and significantly enhance your organization‚Äôs security.

To learn more about HSM-as-a-Service and how Entrust can help you save capital expenditures, maintain control of your critical keys, and strengthen the security of your data, visit the Entrust website.

The post Four considerations when selecting as-a-Service Hardware Security Module solutions to secure your encryption keys appeared first on Entrust Blog.

16:21 • 7 days ago

Elliptic

Sinbad crypto mixer flagged by Elliptic sanctioned and seized

On November 29th 2023, the US Treasury Department‚Äôs Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) sanctioned the Bitcoin mixer Sinbad.io due to its connection to North Korean money laundering. In addition to this designation, Sinbad‚Äôs website now displays a seizure notice.

On November 29th 2023, the US Treasury Department‚Äôs Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) sanctioned the Bitcoin mixer Sinbad.io due to its connection to North Korean money laundering. In addition to this designation, Sinbad‚Äôs website now displays a seizure notice.

16:06 • 7 days ago

1Kosmos BlockID

Possession Is Nine-Tenths of the Flaw: Why Device-based Biometrics Don‚Äôt Cut It for IAM

With credential stuffing attacks on 23andMe and Okta just the latest breaches to make headlines in recent weeks, the push for biometrics-based authentication is gaining momentum for Identity and Access Management (IAM).  The problem: Biometrics aren‚Äôt all created equal. Yes, device-based biometrics such as Touch ID, Face ID, and Windows Hello can help reduce the ‚Ä¶ Continued The post Possess

With credential stuffing attacks on 23andMe and Okta just the latest breaches to make headlines in recent weeks, the push for biometrics-based authentication is gaining momentum for Identity and Access Management (IAM). 

The problem: Biometrics aren‚Äôt all created equal. Yes, device-based biometrics such as Touch ID, Face ID, and Windows Hello can help reduce the threat of password-based account takeover (ATO). But they can still leave IT guessing about the identity behind the device. While hardware tokens and Apple, Microsoft and Google‚Äôs decision to make passkeys the default for logins are also helpful, they really only confirm possession of a device or biometric and assume (but don‚Äôt validate) identity. Thankfully, it doesn‚Äôt have to be this way‚Äîif you have the right IAM architecture.

IAM More Than Just a Device: Enabling F-Word Free Authentication 

Whether it‚Äôs fingerprints or facial recognition, that which is stored can be stolen or spoofed by cybercriminals to infiltrate corporate systems. Hell, even without a hack, traditional forms of biometric authentication only confirm the person accessing an account is the same person who initially enrolled to do so‚Äîbut not whether that person is really who they claim to be. This matters when enrollment fraud leads to more than $3.2 billion in losses annually. For me, ‚Äúfraud‚Äù is an f-word that typically leads to others we could all do without. That‚Äôs where 1Kosmos comes in.  

Identity-Backed Biometrics & Modern IAM Architectures

At 1Kosmos, we saw the urgency of finding a way to easily and accurately verify and authenticate identity in a way that can‚Äôt be vouched for by mere password, one-time passcode, or a static (and spoofable) biometric. That‚Äôs why we set out to modernize IAM by combining strong identity verification and authentication within a unified architecture. One that offers unrivaled identity assurance behind each device used to access online services, along with a seamless account enrollment and authentication experience. In Part One of this series, we provided an overview of this architecture and the pillars it‚Äôs built upon. In this post, let‚Äôs double-click on a core pillar: biometric-based user authentication. 

The 1Kosmos architecture employs automated, digitally verified identity to confirm user claims and credentials with 99.6% accuracy, stores them under user control, and binds them to an identity wallet and biometric with liveness detection. This gives IT the security and control they need while providing users with a seamless login experience. The benefits are threefold: 

High Assurance

Biometrics verified through liveness testing deliver the highest digital identity assurance possible and enable fast, frictionless multi-factor authentication. When matched to a verified identity, they eliminate fraudulent identities hiding behind valid credentials.

User Convenience

Physical attributes used for biometric authentication are not vulnerable to damage and unexpected alterations. They provide quick, user-friendly authentication with or without passwords.

Flexible Use Cases

Whether the use case demands a fingerprint, voice match, a live biometric or other identifier, the 1Kosmos architecture provides affordable authenticators that adjust to varied and evolving business needs.

Building Bulletproof Biometric Authentication

We didn‚Äôt just follow the most effective approach to identity-backed biometric authentication. We defined it. 1Kosmos offers the only IAM architecture built with four crucial elements of identity-backed biometric authentication:  

Certification to FIDO2, NIST 800-63-3 and UKDIATF Standards

Our BlockID platform is certified to FIDO, NIST and UKDIATF standards, having undergone rigorous testing to verify quality coding and ensure the use of common devices to authenticate users. When combined with a verified identity, you‚Äôre talking about unmatched security and convenience. BlockID supports USB keys, keycard authentication, fingerprint readers, and hardware tokens and provides a robust framework to implement or augment passwordless authentication without being forced into using a single provider. With identity-backed biometrics, you also benefit from stronger security using physical traits. Think fingerprint scan with a USB security key or FIDO-compliant facial recognition, for instance. 

iBeta Pad2-Certified Biometrics

As mentioned earlier, biometrics can improve security by replacing or augmenting the use of passwords, but they can also be subject to theft or spoofing. iBeta is an independent, NIST-accredited biometrics testing lab that has developed certification programs to verify biometric applications to recognized standards to prevent these things from happening. When enrolling with our BlockID solution, the user can perform an advanced form of biometrics called a liveness test that prevents false facial verification using a photo, video, mask, or other substitute for an authorized user‚Äôs face. 

Biometric Encryption

Biometric encryption leverages a biometric template and public-private key pair to encrypt and decrypt personally identifiable information for authenticating a user and sharing data with an online service. This approach relies on the uniqueness of biometrics to ensure that hackers can‚Äôt reverse-engineer a password or key. Without the biometric and matching private key, all data in the digital wallet isn‚Äôt accessible, usable, or even legible. There‚Äôs no central storage of user biometrics, ensuring these biometrics remain private. Biometric authentication is easy to use and requires little, if any, user training.  

Flexible Levels of Identity Assurance

With BlockID, you determine the type of biometric appropriate for a given application and the level of identity assurance appropriate to the business risk. For Know Your Customer (KYC) and Know Your Business (KYB) standards, Identity Assurance Level 2 can be achieved using LiveID and identity verification using government-issued credentials, such as a driver‚Äôs license or passport. A liveness test confirms a user‚Äôs facial match to the enrolled biometric and verified documents in real-time. 

Lesser forms of identity assurance can be achieved using information from banking, telco, or corporate databases or through ‚Äúinferred‚Äù identity based on access to an email address or logged-in device, as appropriate for the intended use. For additional use cases, 1Kosmos can also verify a user‚Äôs social security number (SSN) against the SSA, a driver‚Äôs license against the American Association of Vehicle Administrators (AAMVA), a passport against ICAO or the US Department of State, or verify a user is indeed a physician by validating their NPIN (National Physician Information Number). 

As documentation and accounts are enrolled, the location and phone number are verified against the issuing authority. The user‚Äôs LiveID scan is then validated against the picture extracted from the documentation. Once complete, their biometrics are captured, and the data is encrypted with the user‚Äôs private key and stored within a private and permissioned blockchain.

An Unbeatable Advantage 

In Part Three, we‚Äôll drill down on another core pillar of the 1Kosmos architecture: decentralized digital identity and how it provides users with secure anytime, anywhere access to ID cards, driver licenses, social security details, and more through a reusable identity wallet.  

Learn how 1Kosmos can help your organization modernize Identity and Access Management‚Äîvisit our Architectural Advantage page and schedule a demo today.  

 

The post Possession Is Nine-Tenths of the Flaw: Why Device-based Biometrics Don‚Äôt Cut It for IAM appeared first on 1Kosmos.

15:28 • 7 days ago

Elliptic

Black Basta ransomware victims have paid over $100 million

Key takeaways Joint research by Elliptic and Corvus Insurance has identified at least $107 million in Bitcoin ransom payments to the Black Basta ransomware group since early 2022. Black Basta has infected over 329 victims, including Capita, ABB and Dish Network.  Analysis of blockchain transactions shows a clear link between Black Basta and the Conti Group - a Ru
Key takeaways Joint research by Elliptic and Corvus Insurance has identified at least $107 million in Bitcoin ransom payments to the Black Basta ransomware group since early 2022.

Black Basta has infected over 329 victims, including Capita, ABB and Dish Network. 

Analysis of blockchain transactions shows a clear link between Black Basta and the Conti Group - a Russian ransomware gang that ceased operations in 2022, around the time that Black Basta emerged.

Much of the laundered ransom payments can be traced onwards to Garantex, the sanctioned Russian crypto exchange.

 

13:59 • 7 days ago

KuppingerCole

Jan 18, 2024: SAP IDM End of Life: Die IGA-Migration souver√§n meistern

Die Abk√ºndigung von SAP Identity Management (SAP IDM) stellt Unternehmen vor eine kritische Herausforderung. Die bisherige L√∂sung erreicht das Ende ihres Lebenszyklus, und Organisationen m√ºssen sich nun die Frage stellen: Wie kann trotzdem weiterhin Compliance aufrechterhalten werden? Die Gew√§hrleistung der Identit√§tsverwaltung unter Ber√ºcksichtigung der gesetzlichen Bestimmungen entwickelt sich z
Die Abk√ºndigung von SAP Identity Management (SAP IDM) stellt Unternehmen vor eine kritische Herausforderung. Die bisherige L√∂sung erreicht das Ende ihres Lebenszyklus, und Organisationen m√ºssen sich nun die Frage stellen: Wie kann trotzdem weiterhin Compliance aufrechterhalten werden? Die Gew√§hrleistung der Identit√§tsverwaltung unter Ber√ºcksichtigung der gesetzlichen Bestimmungen entwickelt sich zu einem zentralen Anliegen f√ºr Fachleute im Bereich Informationstechnologie. In diesem Kontext suchen Unternehmen nach effektiven Wegen, um die bisherigen Ans√§tze und Verfahren aus dem SAP IDM-Umfeld auf andere Identity Governance and Administration (IGA)-Systeme zu migrieren. SailPoint und IBM pr√§sentieren innovative Ans√§tze, wie moderne Technologien eingesetzt werden k√∂nnen, um IGA-Systeme zu erweitern und deren Vorteile optimal zu nutzen. Dieser Schritt er√∂ffnet neue Wege f√ºr Unternehmen, um ihre Identit√§tsmanagement-Strategien anzupassen und den Herausforderungen des Endes von SAP IDM proaktiv zu begegnen.

UbiSecure

Episode 100 | Digital Identity Buzz: Passwordless, Identity Wallets & Digital Money with Heather Flanagan, Spherical Cow Consulting and David Birch, 15Mb

Let‚Äôs talk about digital identity with Heather Flanagan, Principal at Spherical Cow Consulting and David Birch, Principal at 15 Mb, author, advisor... The post Episode 100 | Digital Identity Buzz: Passwordless, Identity Wallets & Digital Money with Heather Flanagan, Spherical Cow Consulting and David Birch, 15Mb appeared first on Ubisecure Digital Identity Management.
Let‚Äôs talk about digital identity with Heather Flanagan, Principal at Spherical Cow Consulting and David Birch, Principal at 15 Mb, author, advisor and commentator on digital financial services.

This is the 100th episode of Let‚Äôs Talk about Digital Identity ‚Äì in this special episode two of our most popular guests, Heather Flanagan and David Birch, rejoined the podcast to explore what is exciting them in passwordless, identity wallets and digital money.

[Transcript below]

‚ÄúPasswords have got to go. As we‚Äôre moving to passkeys, I think there‚Äôs always room for improvement on ‚Äì even on them. If nothing else, focusing a little bit more on the user experience so that people will have a better understanding of what this means.‚Äù

Heather Flanagan, Principal at Spherical Cow Consulting and choreographer for Identity Flash Mob, comes from a position that the Internet is led by people, powered by words, and inspired by technology. She has been involved in leadership roles with some of the most technical, volunteer-driven organisations on the Internet, including IDPro as Principal Editor, the IETF, the IAB, and the IRTF as RFC Series Editor, ICANN as Technical Writer, and REFEDS as Coordinator, just to name a few. If there is work going on to develop new Internet standards, or discussions around the future of digital identity, she is interested in engaging in that work.

Listen Episode 74, where Heather discusses Making Identity Easy for Everyone or connect with Heather on LinkedIn.

‚ÄúThe thing that‚Äôs broken in digital money at the moment, is identity, not the payment bit.‚Äù

David G.W Birch is an author, advisor and commentator on digital financial services. Principal at 15Mb, his advisory company, he is Global Ambassador for the secure electronic transactions consultancy, Consult Hyperion, Fintech Ambassador for Digital Jersey and Non-Executive Chair at Digiseq Ltd. He is an internationally-recognised thought leader in digital identity and digital money. Ranked one of the top 100 fintech influencers for 2021, previously named one of the global top 15 favourite sources of business information by Wired magazine and one of the top ten most influential voices in banking by Financial Brand, he created one of the top 25 ‚Äúmust read‚Äù financial IT blogs and was found by PR Daily to be one of the top ten Twitter accounts followed by innovators (along with Bill Gates and Richard Branson).

His latest book ‚ÄúThe Currency Cold War‚ÄîCash and Cryptography, Hash Rates and Hegemony‚Äù (published in May 2020) ‚Äúpaints a fascinating and stimulating picture of the future of the world of digital payments and its possible impact on the wider global and economic orders‚Äù ‚Äì Philip Middleton, OMFIF Digital Monetary Institute. His previous book ‚ÄúBefore Babylon, Beyond Bitcoin: From money we understand to money that understands us‚Äù was published in June 2017 with a foreword by Andrew Haldane, Chief Economist at the Bank of England. The LSE Review of Books said the book should be ‚Äúwidely read by graduate students of finance, financial law and related topics as well as policy makers involved in financial regulation‚Äù.  The London Review of Books called his earlier book ‚ÄúIdentity is the New Money‚Äù fresh, original, wide-ranging and ‚Äúthe best book on general issues around new forms of money‚Äù.

More information is available at dgwbirch.com and you can follow him @dgwbirch on X.

Listen to Episode 75 with David discussing Digital Currencies or connect with David on LinkedIn.

We‚Äôll be continuing this conversation on X using #LTADI ‚Äì join us @ubisecure!

Go to @Ubisecure on YouTube to watch the video transcript for episode 100.

Podcast transcript

Oscar Santolalla: This is episode number 100 of Let‚Äôs Talk About Digital Identity. And for this special occasion, we have invited back Heather Flanagan, and David Birch.

Let‚Äôs Talk About Digital Identity, the podcast connecting identity and business. I am your host, Oscar Santolalla.

We have invited back to the show two of our most popular guests. So, these two guests, let me introduce them is Heather Flanagan. She is Principal at Spherical Cow Consulting and Acting Executive Director for IDPro. Hello, Heather.

Heather Flanagan: Hello, Oscar.

Oscar: Nice having you back.

And our second guest is David Birch. David Birch is an author, advisor and commentator on digital financial services. He is Principal at 15 Mb, his advisory company. Hello, David.

David Birch: Hi. Thanks for having me.

Oscar: It‚Äôs a real pleasure having you both for this special episode, a bit different style, so being out of our usual script. But yeah, hearing a little bit more about yourselves.

So, I‚Äôd like to hear something in particular, because we want to hear something ‚Äì a moment in your lives. So, what I want to hear ‚Äì think of one specific moment in your career in which you told yourself, ‚ÄúYes, this is why I love working in the identity industry.‚Äù Which moment would it be? Who wants to start?

David: Well, and it‚Äôs a bit self-centred, but probably when my publisher agreed to publish my first book. I thought I had some interesting ideas about identity ‚Äì I mean you always think that your ideas are ‚Äì but when you get that kind of validation that your ideas actually are interesting to other people. That really did change my career. Yeah, otherwise, I probably would have just carried on being a pretty average consultant and carried on in payments and banking. So yeah, it‚Äôs ‚Äì but I put it all down to my publisher.

Oscar: Which one was this book? Tell us which book was this.

David: Identity is the New Money. It was Diane Coyle, the Economist, who encouraged me to publish it. So yeah.

Oscar: Fantastic. Heather?

Heather: I don‚Äôt have anything. I‚Äôve been actually thinking about this question for a while, and it‚Äôs really hard to point to any one thing, because there were no lightning from the sky moments. It‚Äôs just, it‚Äôs always been such a foundational aspect of everything that I‚Äôve ever done since I started in tech in the mid ‚Äò90s. Where the first question was always ‚Äì when you‚Äôre taking over something from a bulletin board system to an email server, ‚ÄúWho can access this? What permissions do they need to have? How do you set up accounts for them?‚Äù That was where everything always started. So, no one moment, it‚Äôs all of the moments.

Oscar: Well, that‚Äôs great that there are several exciting moments. I‚Äôm sure for all of us, it‚Äôs been like that. Several moments in which we feel that this is exciting to be in this industry. But thank you for sharing that with us.

Being already towards the end of this year 2023 ‚Äì so there are some keywords which were buzzing in the last years. But some of these buzzwords today are more reality, we have access to those. What do you think, what you feel about these technologies or techniques. And let‚Äôs get started with passwordless. So, if I ask Heather, what excites you today about passwordless?

Heather: I‚Äôm really excited about the fact that the technology itself is solid, the standards themselves are really, really well-done. But as excited as I am, I am concerned. Like at all the new modern technologies, I look at them and go, ‚ÄúWow, that‚Äôs really cool.‚Äù and little anxiety making because for passwordless, what I observe is when you actually get out of the tech field and talk to my mother, she doesn‚Äôt trust it because it‚Äôs too easy.

And so, I do wonder about as bad as passwords are, the friction that they add, it‚Äôs something that people can wrap their heads around. Whereas they don‚Äôt understand the magic that‚Äôs happening behind the scenes that makes passkeys better. And if they don‚Äôt trust it, they won‚Äôt use it. And if they don‚Äôt use it, we lose out on all the benefits. So, one of the things I‚Äôve been trying to think about for you know, the future is OK passkeys are amazing, but how can we make them less magic scary?

David: I‚Äôm a bit frustrated with it really, because I‚Äôm extremely lazy. And so, you know, like eBay, for example, uses passkeys, the whole thing works perfectly. So as soon as I go to a site, as in fact I just did 10 minutes ago to look at something and it‚Äôs log back in. I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúWhat I have an account? I didn‚Äôt even know I had the account.‚Äù And then I had to remember the password. And of course, I didn‚Äôt get it. So, I had to click on, I forgot my password, and then I got the password reset. And then I put in the new password. And it said, ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt have a new password that‚Äôs the same as the old password.‚Äù And we just go around in this loop. And it drives me crazy. I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt you just all implement this?‚Äù Despite the fears of your mom, which I mean I can‚Äôt discount those because they‚Äôre real. The sooner we make people stop using passwords, the better.

I was reading a fantastic story in the Insider this morning. Did you see this story about the Zelle fraud on Insider? It‚Äôs typical kind of thing, you know, guys getting some work done by a contractor. The hackers get into the contractor‚Äôs email account, they send him a thing to send money to a different account, which is the hackers‚Äô account. And they make off with all of the money. And so, they go and talk to the contractor and said to him, ‚ÄúYou know, did you know that your email has been compromised, you should change your email password.‚Äù

And the guy, it says in the article, ‚ÄúWe may as well have been speaking Romanian.‚Äù The guy had absolutely no idea what they were talking about. Because he‚Äôs a normal person. He doesn‚Äôt care about all of this stuff. You don‚Äôt say to people, ‚ÄúOh, here‚Äôs a car, would you like a seat belt with it? Or would you like a piece of string that you could attach in, you know, particularly opt in place.‚Äù You know, as a society, it comes to a point where you say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, not wearing seatbelts, there‚Äôs just too many people dying. So, cars have to have seatbelts. And you have to put the damn things on. End of story.‚Äù

And I sort of feel we‚Äôre getting to that point. Fraud and scam, it‚Äôs just so completely out of control. And this thing about whether you know, you need to put people in charge of their own data and so on. I just don‚Äôt believe that for a moment. I just don‚Äôt. Most people don‚Äôt have the persistent competence that ‚Äì including me, by the way, I‚Äôm not casting the first stone, I‚Äôm one of those people that lacks the persistent competence to make this happen. There are reservations but passkeys are a billion times better than passwords, and we should make people use them. I‚Äôm sorry, you got to stop pandering to populism.

Heather: No two ways about it ‚Äì Passwords have got to go. As we‚Äôre moving to passkeys, I think there‚Äôs always room for improvement on ‚Äì even on them. If nothing else, focusing a little bit more on the user experience so that people will have a better understanding of what this means. And when they click this button, why would they click this as opposed to clicking something else that might be a phishing site that they wouldn‚Äôt recognise. So, it‚Äôs an ongoing education.

David: Then you sort of think of contactless as the, you know, in the early days of contactless people, ‚ÄúOh, it‚Äôs too scary.‚Äù And in some parts of the world, it appears to be witchcraft, that you can pay for things by not touching it with your card and this, people are going to come and steal all the cards. And there are going to be people of Eastern European origin on the subway system, putting their hands inside your clothes to read your cards and all this. Remember all of this stuff that was going on?

And now, you walk into a store, anywhere in the world. I‚Äôm not talking America, I‚Äôm talking about developed countries, of course. You walk into a store anywhere in the world, and there‚Äôs that little contactless symbol and you pay, and you go, and no one thinks anything about it anymore. It‚Äôs a bit different in America. In America, you have to look for the till and where‚Äôs the sign? And then you have to press some buttons. And then sometimes you have to sign something as well. It‚Äôs baffling. I don‚Äôt understand any of it.

Heather: Oh, the day you understand what happens in the United States will be a marvellous day. Because nobody understands what happens.

David: No, it‚Äôs mysterious. But the point is, generally speaking, you know, we came up with this symbol, and everybody knows, you tap your card there, and it works. And guess what? All of your money isn‚Äôt stolen by Eastern European fraudsters. So, they‚Äôre not all Eastern European, obviously, other fraudsters are available. Because the corollary is going to be basically, people like us will start using passkeys, and so all the fraud will transfer onto people like your mom. That seems a little unfair to me.

Oscar: Yeah, seeing that you are excited indeed with passwordless. But of course, there are some concerns and some things to improve. Absolutely. Interesting what Heather said that, yeah, some people have been using password for so long, but that anything else feels like how do you say the‚Ä¶

David: An improvement? Real security? System-wide integrity? I don‚Äôt know, what‚Äôs the word you‚Äôre searching for there? I don‚Äôt know.

Oscar: How you say the‚Ä¶

Heather: Magic.

Oscar: Magic. Yeah, magic.

David: So, I‚Äôm excited as Heather is, I‚Äôm probably just a bit more militant on how quickly we should be pushing it out.

Oscar: Yeah, we‚Äôll see what comes in the next year as how it really rolls out. But the next one is about identity wallets. So, what excites you today about identity wallets?

Heather: Oh, I have a list on that one. I‚Äôm particularly excited over how ‚Äì as much as I worry about people not understanding the magic, they do understand the concept of flipping through a wallet to get to the right card, the right credential, the right thing they need and then using it and giving them that level of control is a vast improvement, I think over some of the other technology has been going on today.

I‚Äôm watching what‚Äôs happening in Europe quite closely because I think that ‚Äì how the governments are handling digital wallets and digital identity is a very interesting model. I will be curious to see how other countries do it. How they do it well, how they do it poorly. And if there‚Äôs some way we can actually ‚Äì I‚Äôd love to standardise ‚Äòwhat‚Äôs a wallet‚Äô, you know. That‚Äôs one of my little pet peeves, there is no standard for a wallet. There‚Äôs standard for credentials, but there‚Äôs not a standard for ‚Äòwhat is a wallet‚Äô.

David: I mean, it‚Äôs interesting to see what the Open Wallet initiative and various other people are doing in this space. I agree with Heather. I think as much as the technology is important, and certainly, in technological terms, the wallet is the sort of crucial pivot between the kind of online and offline world. It‚Äôs very central to the next phase of evolution of commerce. A lot of it has to do with ‚Äì in fact, we won‚Äôt even call our wallets now identity wallets, we just call them wallets. But if you actually open up my wallet, I mean, I won‚Äôt do it over there. If you open up my wallet, it has no money in it. Everything is in my wallet, it has to do with identity, driver‚Äôs licenses and loyalty cards. And my wallet is already an identity wallet, we just don‚Äôt call it that.

So, extending that wallet across sort of virtual and real world seems to me, pretty straightforward. But of course, that does rather interestingly open up what I think will be quite a vicious battle about who‚Äôs actually going to control those wallets. Because certainly, Heather mentioned kind of the European approach. They‚Äôre very, very unhappy with the idea of big tech controlling those wallets. We‚Äôre very unhappy with the big tech or big government controlling the wallets. People like me will prefer that it was regulated institutions ‚Äì banks primarily, that control those wallets. Other people think banks should be absolutely the last people to have any sort of control over those wallets. So really, I‚Äôm not smart enough to figure out like the end dimensional gameplay as to how this is going to work out. But it‚Äôs pretty serious. It‚Äôs pretty serious.

Heather: Yeah, people understand the concept of a wallet. But what we‚Äôre talking about in today‚Äôs world is that, you know, ‚Äúhow many wallets are you going to have to carry?‚Äù Because there may be one that‚Äôs issued by big tech, perhaps via your browser or via your mobile device. But then, you know, as governments are saying, ‚ÄúNo, we‚Äôre going to issue something that‚Äôs completely separate and have its own app, and what is that going to look like. And then how are people supposed to be able to find the credential they need across 2, 3, 5 different wallets?

David: No, I agree with you completely on that, Heather. But I think there‚Äôs another level of complexity there as well, which is ‚Äì because is the wallet going to be like if you imagine there‚Äôs some kind of standard wallet, is that wallet the app? Or is that wallet, essentially the underlying SDK the apps plug into?

So, my British Airways app and my Barclays Bank app, they‚Äôre all actually the same wallet underneath. They‚Äôre all plugging into the same wallet. But is it going to be like that? Is there going to be like a travel industry wallet? Or is British Airways going to have its own wallet? That‚Äôs really hard to know. I would think, and this comes from kind of what I think is a reasonably rational calculus. The credentials that are going to be in those wallets are the embodiment of individual reputations.

My British Airways credential is the embodiment of my relationship with British Airways, that I want to take and show to other people. It‚Äôs not obvious to me that British Airways would benefit from owning the wallet, because they‚Äôd have to maintain it and upgrade it and whatever. They‚Äôre having enough trouble just with their own website to do that. On the other hand, I can see why they‚Äôd be nervous about just handing the whole thing over to Apple and Google, because then they‚Äôll end up paying a tax, which I‚Äôm pretty sure they don‚Äôt want to do. So, I don‚Äôt know how that‚Äôs going to work out. But I listen to a lot of smart people about this. It‚Äôs a very fascinating topic to me.

Heather: I talked to Don Thibeau and Juliana Cafik and a couple others about ‚Äúwhat was the Open Wallet Foundation trying to do?‚Äù And they‚Äôre trying to work towards interoperability in code and maybe a standard will come out of that someday when they see what works and what doesn‚Äôt work. But at the moment, they are not standardising wallets. They‚Äôre just‚Ä¶

David: No, that‚Äôs true. There‚Äôs‚Ä¶

Heather: They‚Äôre just putting together a platform to try and make it work together.

David: But as you pointed out earlier on, some of the components are standardised. We have VCs, we have MDL. We‚Äôve got MDL 7 and 9 coming in a few months, a year or something. So I mean, there is some pretty useful standardisation going on anyway.

Heather: Yeah, more in the credential format space.

David: Yeah, yeah. Yeah, absolutely. That might give us enough interoperability to get started.

Oscar: We‚Äôll see. Indeed, it sounds like it‚Äôs‚Ä¶

David: I‚Äôm a naturally simple and optimistic person. Heather‚Äôs looking at all the nuances here. And that‚Äôs why she‚Äôs so, that‚Äôs why my superficial, cheery approach to this ‚Äì it‚Äôs not washing with her I can see it from her face.

Oscar: You seem to be both excited about identity wallets, I think.

David: Yeah, I think wallets are really interesting topic for the coming year.

Heather: Huge potential.

Oscar: You, David, mentioned that as far as I understood, you don‚Äôt carry cash anymore, that was my understanding how you have your wallet, your real wallet without cash.

David: No, actually, I mean I don‚Äôt carry my real wallet, it‚Äôs in the drawer over there. So, I had an interesting conversation with somebody last week about premium cards. That‚Äôs how interesting my life is, Heather. I just, I benchmark, I had an interesting discussion with someone else last week about premium cards. This is a tragic trajectory of my life.

But I have this fancy new American Express Platinum Card, which is made out of some sort of metal. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs actually platinum, but it‚Äôs sort of metal. And it‚Äôs really fancy and heavy and solid and whatever. And I couldn‚Äôt even tell you where it is. It‚Äôs in the house somewhere. I haven‚Äôt the slightest idea.

Oscar: Don‚Äôt activate it.

David: No, no, because as soon as I got it, it‚Äôs on my phone. I only ever use it on my phone. I don‚Äôt know where the actual card is, I have no interest in that. I‚Äôm going into London in a minute, I have a ring. So, the ring I use for getting on the subway and bus because I don‚Äôt always want to take my phone out. But if I‚Äôm paying in a restaurant so I got to use my phone. I think the days of physical wallets, I mean, lots of people keep saying, well, there‚Äôs going to be a backlash at some point, and people are going to want to use cash, sort of the way they want to use vinyl records, I suppose. But I think that will just be like a few hipsters. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôll be the rest of us.

Heather: I don‚Äôt trust having network access consistently enough to go without some kind of physical something. Do I use my wallet on my watch and my phone more often than not? Well, when I‚Äôm in Europe, yes. When I‚Äôm in the US, maybe. I don‚Äôt count on it. I don‚Äôt think I can count on it yet. So, there‚Äôs always the physical components that I think I have to have.

David: Yeah, I mean, I would say that‚Äôs an interesting argument in favour of using offline verifiable credentials. And it‚Äôs also a crucial argument in favour as to why Central Bank Digital Currency should operate offline. So, I mean, I agree with you about that. As to the state of things at the moment, well, if the transit gates fail and can‚Äôt go online, they have to fail open, it‚Äôs a public safety issue. You can‚Äôt fail transit gate shut. So, they have to, they should have ‚Äì I can always get home, you know, but it‚Äôs never happened. But when push comes to shove, I‚Äôll get home, so I‚Äôm fine.

Oscar: Yes, and that related to my last question, but just to hear what you liked the most. So, what excites you about this digital money that we were already starting to discuss?

David: I‚Äôd say there‚Äôs probably three things. I mean, Heather‚Äôs going to disagree with me on every single one of them, which is why it makes for an interesting conversation. But I‚Äôd say there‚Äôs probably three things.

So, the first thing is digital money, well, certainly digital currency is the subject of irrational delusional comment by conspiracy theorists, which makes for entertainment. So, I get emails, ‚Äúoh, you know, Central Bank Digital Currency is the mark of the devil. And we know this because Bill Gates implanted microchips in us through the vaccine, and the microchips are going to steal the digital currency from unvaccinated people and send it through the 5g towers to Satan.‚Äù Or somebody, I can‚Äôt remember exactly, I don‚Äôt remember. But you get emails like this, which add to the gaiety of the nation.

So, the first thing is, there are parts of America where non-existent digital currency is already being banned. So, this is all getting a bit, sort of witch trail-y, so that‚Äôs quite entertaining.

The second thing is, and I wasn‚Äôt joking about that offline point, which is any scale digital currency in any developed country, even where you have networks and infrastructure has to work offline. It‚Äôs the crucial design requirement of it. If you‚Äôre going to have a cash substitute, it has to work offline. And that, for me, poses very interesting technological problems, all of which I think, have already been solved. But nonetheless, it‚Äôs really intellectually interesting, so I sort of like that.

And the third thing is, I think a lot of people look at digital currency as ‚Äòthe thing‚Äô. Like, you know, we need digital currency. And that‚Äôs it. I mean, what we need is a platform for innovation and development. Digital currency in itself is sort of not that interesting. As we‚Äôve just established, I can already buy milk in the supermarket without using physical cash. So that‚Äôs not, but this idea of permissionless innovation that you could bring into our space from the cryp‚Äì because digital it doesn‚Äôt involve any credit risk, you see. So, you could imagine a situation where as long as you‚Äôve got an approved chip in your iPhone, or something, they‚Äôre certified as being capable of storing digital dollars or something like that, then you can use the API to do whatever you like, there‚Äôs no credit risk involved. So, allowing people to experiment with interesting new things ‚Äì micro payments, and Escrow and blah, blah, blah. On top of it is really where it‚Äôs at. And that‚Äôs why, you know, I get it a bit when people say, ‚ÄúWell, what are the sort of key uses?‚Äù Well, I don‚Äôt know, I‚Äôm too old. Give it to some kids in a garage and let them come up with something.

Heather: OK. So, for one thing, I really want to see your emails about this because they sound hilarious. I admit, I‚Äôm absolutely a digital currency sceptic. For one thing, as David has said, right, you don‚Äôt generally need to carry cash now anyway, so what is it getting you? And everything I understand about it is like, ‚ÄúWell, yes, but then you‚Äôll be able to transfer money quickly without the bank getting in the way.‚Äù And I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúHmm, you say the bank getting in the way and verifying the transaction is a bad thing.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, but it‚Äôs expensive.‚Äù And I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôs a different problem, not just because the banks are charging a lot.‚Äù So that‚Äôs like a completely different problem to solve that it‚Äôs not a technology problem at all.

So yeah, I‚Äôm definitely not convinced. Having the permission to innovate and work with this kind of currency, to me in a way, that‚Äôs like saying, ‚ÄúYup, let‚Äôs turn this into a barter system, except you‚Äôre bartering these digital currency components.‚Äù ‚ÄúOK. Go for it, go to town.‚Äù That‚Äôs just people agreeing with each other. And it‚Äôs a completely different system in the same way that a barter system is completely different with my cash system.

David: That‚Äôs a really interesting point. And I don‚Äôt mean that in any sort of patronising sense, I really mean that because you‚Äôre right, of course. And what that means is, if this stuff worked, then downstream you could imagine an environment where if you and I engage in some sort of transaction, right, I‚Äôm going to pay you to write something or you‚Äôre going to pay me to come and speak or something like that. My, you know, supercomputer at the end of a wire, it can be a through my mobile phone, my giant killer robot artificially intelligent wallet will negotiate with your super intelligent giant killer robot Terminator wallet to exchange baskets of tokens to an agreed ‚Äì

The idea that you would need money as an intermediary when you have that kind of barter that works. I think that‚Äôs really, that‚Äôs as a very interesting point. So, if our super computers could agree on these baskets of assets to exchange, which sounds weird when its people talking about it, but it‚Äôs a few nanoseconds for super computers. Why would you turn those assets into dollars or something in the first place? Why wouldn‚Äôt you just swap the assets around?

So, I actually rather agree with that point. But I think that‚Äôs much further downstream. I think, in the short term, you see the demand for dollar stable coins in particular, as an indication to me that a lot of people around the world and in America, for that matter, wants to hold digital dollars. They would find digital dollars useful to do things with that you can‚Äôt do with regular dollars, and I sort of agree.

So, I can see sort of both things. But to me, the short term and the long term are quite different there. Because I probably do drink my Kool Aid, and I‚Äôd probably do think that that‚Äôs kind of a stupid expression actually it‚Äôs, don‚Äôt drink that Kool Aid because everybody that drank the Kool Aid died, didn‚Äôt they? Or am I getting the stories mixed up?

Heather: I wasn‚Äôt going to say it.

David: Yeah, no, I think they did. OK, that‚Äôs a bad example. But the point is, I think in the long run, you might well be right. I think in the short term, digital currencies, I think would add to the net welfare. I mean, I can imagine, you and I agreeing to something, and the money just goes from my digital wallet to your digital wallet. It never goes anywhere near the banking system. It just goes over Bluetooth or whatever but yes. It is exciting. That‚Äôs true.

Oscar: Heather, what‚Äôs not so exciting to digital money?

Heather: We‚Äôll see.

Oscar: We‚Äôll see. We‚Äôll see. Anything else that it‚Äôs for you is exciting?

David: What‚Äôs not working digital money, you know, these answers are intertwined, because the thing that‚Äôs broken in digital money at the moment, is identity, not the payment bit. Like the reason why you‚Äôve got Zelle frauds and authorised push payment frauds and these massive crypto scams going on all the time. It‚Äôs because nobody knows who anybody is. It‚Äôs not because the payments don‚Äôt work properly. It‚Äôs because identity doesn‚Äôt work properly.

If the identity, you know, I‚Äôm going to sound like a broken record on this one for the teenagers there. I‚Äôm going to sound like a vinyl implement that used to go around whether it has a scratch in it. So, this sort of needle would prompt up, down and come back to this, I have to talk them through this metaphor. But I‚Äôm going to sound like a broken record on this. Because if you fix the identity problem, payments are easy.

If you know the reputation of all of the counterparties in a transaction, then pricing the risk in that transaction is easy. And that‚Äôs kind of what we should be aiming for. The next phase of evolution is really about identity. It happens that I think, and I can‚Äôt prove this with any kind of actual analysis, this is just my sort of crackpot theory about this. But actually, if central banks do drive forward with digital currency, digital currency doesn‚Äôt work unless you have digital identity. You can‚Äôt give people wallets unless you know who those people are. You can‚Äôt maintain limits on personal holdings unless you know who‚Äôs got the wallets. There must be an identity system for the currency system to work. So it could be that Central Bank Digital Currency actually turns out to be a vector for people like Heather to actually get something done about wallets and digital identity. So, there‚Äôs an interesting interrelationship there.

Heather: They are certainly tied together. There‚Äôs no two questions about that.

Oscar: Anything else that you think that is exciting today in the identity world that we have not covered?

David: Well, there‚Äôs two things I‚Äôm excited about today. I can tell you what I was doing before I came on this call. So, one is ‚Äì I‚Äôm very excited about only because I‚Äôm not a normal person. I‚Äôm very excited about ultra-wideband technology. So, all iPhones for a while, you know some of the top end Samsung‚Äôs you know Apple Air Tags, things like this, they all have this thing in them called you UWB, Ultra-Wideband which a lot of people kind of overlook a little bit because we focus everything on Bluetooth and Wi-Fi. But when Bluetooth and Wi Fi came out there were actually three wireless standards. There was Bluetooth, UWB and Wi-Fi. And UWB never really got used because the Wi-Fi chips got cheaper much quicker, and everybody just started building Wi-Fi into things. And meanwhile Bluetooth ranges went up.

But ultra-wideband, which is short range, medium speed that uses this pulsed radio. Because of the way it works, it can only tell where things are, this is how Air Tags work. But it can also tell whether you‚Äôre moving towards something or away from it. So, this idea of having a phone that knows you‚Äôre walking up to the point-of-sale terminal or knows you‚Äôre walking up to a door. And the way that Apple are part of this digital car keys alliance, which I‚Äôm very interested in with Google, and I think BMW and people like that.

So, this idea that you have one technology like this, which locates you, you‚Äôre walking towards the POS terminal, and then it flips to Bluetooth to execute an actually secure transaction with real cryptography, and real keys. I‚Äôm really interested in that at the moment for a variety of different ways. So that‚Äôs the first thing.

And the second thing is, and I think we have touched on this before, we think of identity as being about people. But actually, everything needs identity. And when everything has an identity, working out how to get both privacy and security in that environment is really rather complicated. It‚Äôs very intellectually challenging. And that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm spending the rest of my time on with another startup at the moment. So yeah, there‚Äôs no end of things to be excited about in this space, honestly. And frankly, figuring out how people can log into their bank account without password is the least interesting of the things that‚Äôs going on at the moment.

Heather: Probably the most interesting thing that I‚Äôm trying to stay on top of right now is watching the standards development space, because that is like one of my favourite things to do. Because I might also be a little bit of a strange person. So, standards development space, seeing how ISO, the IETF, the W3C, as well as some of the smaller standard‚Äôs organisations like the OpenID Foundation, the Decentralised Identity Foundation, Trust Over IP, how they‚Äôre all circling closer and closer to each other and sometimes hitting each other, bouncing off.

You know, it‚Äôs becoming a really dense space to try and follow and understand what‚Äôs happening with W3C verifiable credentials? How do those relate to the ISO MDOC standards, and what‚Äôs happening with the IETF‚Äôs OAuth and CBOR and you know, all of these different standard‚Äôs groups are all starting to get closer and closer at nibbling down this problem. And they‚Äôre never going to succeed because they‚Äôre reaching the point where it‚Äôs not a technical problem anymore. It‚Äôs a societal problem. And the regulators are starting to move ahead of them and saying, ‚ÄúNo, this is what, you know, we need to happen. And it‚Äôs not about technology, as much as it is sometimes about the society and the cultural requirements.‚Äù So, seeing these organisations tighten up, it‚Äôs pretty cool.

David: I was just going to ask you, because I‚Äôve sort of lost the thread on this a little bit, because unless you follow it with minute detail every day, you don‚Äôt. I wonder if the whole kind of MDOC thing doesn‚Äôt have its own momentum. So, in other words, in a lot of circumstances, you can see why people are going to go to MDOC and MDL part 5, even for something that‚Äôs not a driving license, just because. It reminds me a little bit, and here‚Äôs another one of the teenagers, it reminds me of X.500. Because having spent part of my young life, she doesn‚Äôt even know what X.500 is, how he‚Äôs been part of my ‚Äì X.400 was the ISO messaging standard that existed before the internet and that no longer exists. And X.500 was the directory standard for that. And that no longer exists. An X.509 was the standard for exchanging public keys in that directory. And X.509 version 3 is how everything works on the internet.

So, the whole of X.400 has disappeared, the whole of X.500 disappeared. And I just wonder if MDL isn‚Äôt going to be in the same place, like people are going to end up using MDL just because it exists. It may not be the optimum for a lot of the appli‚Äì but it doesn‚Äôt matter. The format exists. Wallets can understand it. Apple and Google Wallets can understand it. The MDOC stuff will carry on standardising, and I think maybe a lot of stuff will just get sucked into that.

Heather: What‚Äôs getting complicated about it ‚Äì is the MDL standards. They are in their own way the X.509 to the modern world. They‚Äôre specifying a credential. This is a discrete concrete, and this is what this is supposed to be used for. It is your driver‚Äôs license. It is your identifier. Verifiable credentials using W3 capital V, capital C verifiable credentials. That‚Äôs not what they are really, those are much more generic thing that‚Äôs actually more an authentication thing. So, the fact that they‚Äôre hitting each other in the ways that they are is very interesting and a little disturbing. And the fact that the browser vendors are debating within themselves, which one they‚Äôre going to support when ultimately, they serve different purposes, I worry that we‚Äôre going to be driven towards‚Ä¶

David: No, no, I‚Ä¶ your analysis is spot on. I agree with you completely Heather. I‚Äôm just saying that in practice, what seems to be happening is like people like me would say, ‚ÄúWell, actually‚Ä¶‚Äù you know, use the canonical example going into the bar, you know, people like me would say, ‚ÄúWell, you should be presenting an ISO W3C verifiable credential that says that you‚Äôre over 18 or over 21. So, I‚Äôm going‚Ä¶‚Äù But that doesn‚Äôt exist. The standard for the credential exists, but the contents, whereas on MDL, OK, that‚Äôs not really what it was meant for. But actually, demanding to see your MDL driver‚Äôs license, I can do because the standard exists. And I, you know, so I agree with your analysis. I‚Äôm just saying I wonder if actually, well, Trust Over IP and all these other things are kind of circling around, bumping into each other. MDOC is just steadily progressing, you know.

Heather: Told you Oscar, I told you, you‚Äôre going to have all sorts of fun things to talk about.

David: He‚Äôs going to get very bored on our ‚Äì just our island, Heather. Like after the plane crashes, we‚Äôre going to be fine. He‚Äôs going to be, I don‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs going to do all day, making those little token at men or something.

Oscar: Yeah, fantastic. Hearing all this from you. You‚Äôre definitely super passionate about ‚Äì many of these things that you‚Äôre talking about, frustrated about some of them, but yes, super excited about most of them. So, thank you very much for joining us in very special episode for us. So, thank you very much. And please tell us how people can learn more about you, Heather?

Heather: Oh, easiest thing is ‚Äì go to LinkedIn and find me there. I check it every day. It‚Äôs one of my major social media accounts.

David: Yeah, I mean, I spend more time on LinkedIn now since Twitter kind of went all weird. So, I mean, I‚Äôm on LinkedIn too. But it also you can just look up www.dgwbirch.com.

Oscar: Excellent. Well, thank you very much. So, let‚Äôs see how exciting comes the next coming months, years and yeah, how all the things we were discussing today will roll out. So, again, thanks a lot and all the best.

Heather: Great. Bye

David: Bye guys. Talk soon.

Thanks for listening to this episode of Let‚Äôs Talk About Digital Identity produced by Ubisecure. Stay up to date with episode at ubisecure.com/podcast or join us on Twitter @ubisecure and use the #LTADI. Until next time.

Explainer Federated Identity and SSI - YMMV 2023-11-17 Spherical Cow Consulting

Both Federated Identity and SSI models support similar (but not wholly overlapping) use cases. For example, both models can support remote identification, authentication, and/or authorization to online services. Both require an entity that holds the source records, issues credentials, and supports the possibility of a third party using those credentials. 

Self-Sovereign Identity vs. UNDP‚Äôs Digital Public Infrastructure 2023-11-19 LionsGate Digital

In the digital era, the quest for a secure and efficient identity management system has led to the emergence of two distinct philosophies: Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) and the United Nations Development Program‚Äôs (UNDP) digital public infrastructure (DPI) approach as recently endorsed by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.

[wVideo] Ethics vs Human-Centered Design in Identity 2023-11-20 Talking Identity

Introduction to Value Sensitive Design

Value Sensitive Design and Information Systems

Translating Values into Design Requirements

Ethics for the Digital Age: Where Are the Moral Specs? (Value Sensitive Design and Responsible Innovation)

An Ethical Framework for Evaluating Experimental Technology

Ethics-by-Design:Project SHERPA

Value sensitive design as a formative framework

EBSI Reboot Belgium to focus on a public sector European blockchain during its EU presidency 2023-11-21 Science|Business

‚ÄúA lot of countries are working on applications based on the blockchain; it would be a good idea to build them on a common infrastructure. But it has to be on a blockchain which is managed by the government,‚Äù he said.

Michel is proposing to reboot the European Blockchain Services Infrastructure (EBSI) project set up by the European Commission in 2018, in collaboration with the European Blockchain partnership, made up of the 27 EU member states plus Norway and Liechtenstein.

Belgium Proposes Blockchain Infrastructure for Europe 2023-11-22 COINTURK NEWS

The revamped EBSI project will be renamed Europeum and will be used by public administration tasks such as verifying driver‚Äôs licenses and other official documents throughout the EU. According to Michel, the project could also support the digital Euro infrastructure. He emphasized the importance of using a public blockchain infrastructure developed by EU member states instead of private alternatives:

Standards [Report] GLOBAL STANDARDS MAPPING INITIATIVE 4.0 2023-11 Global Blockchain Business Council

Since 2020, Global Blockchain Business Council (GBBC) has kept the industry up to date with the Global Standards Mapping Initiative (GSMI), the most comprehensive industry-focused effort to map and analyze the blockchain and digital assets community across six key areas:

1. Legislation & Regulatory Developments
2. Taxonomy
3. Technical Standards
4. Blockchain & Digital Assets Landscape
5. Courses from Accredited Educational Institutions
6. In-Depth Reports & Visuals on Key Themes

[tweet] Excited to announce that VC-JSON-Schema has progressed to Candidate Recommendation at the @w3c 2023-11-21 decentralgabe

it's now that much easier (& legitimate) to use JSON Schemas with Verifiable Credentials

Government [USA mDL] A Digital Toast: My Encounter with Louisiana's Mobile Driver's License 2023-11-18 TBD

Recognized legally as an equalivalent to physical identification, LA Wallet is my go-to for age-restricted purchases/entry, voting, and (heaven forbid) police encounters. Because of this, the mDL ensures legal compliance and security while leveraging the convenience and accessibility of mobile technology. They accomplish this by using Verifiable Credentials.

[Explainer] Introducing European Digital Identity (EUDI): The Future of Secure and Accessible Identity 2023-11-20 Ubisecure

This wallet integrates various attributes and credentials, ensuring they are stored and managed with utmost security and respect for privacy. As an integral part of the EU digital identity and trust services framework, EUDI extends beyond the wallet, offering a comprehensive solution for digital identity management across the European Union.

[Canada] Credivera‚Äôs workforce digital identity platform put to the test by govt agency 2023-11-23 Biometric Update

A release from Canadian digital identity firm Credivera says the company has entered the last phase of testing before commercialization under the Innovative Solutions Canada (ISC) program.

[Canada] EBSI-CAN 2023-11-24 3CL Foundation

EBSI-CAN explores the potential for the European Blockchain Services Infrastructure (EBSI) to be deployed as a verifiable, cross-border credentialing framework in Canada, levering on use-cases for cross-issuance, cross verification and cross-recognition with the centre of learners when traveling between the EU and Canada.

Organization [USA] TrustEd Microcredential Coalition Aims to Maximize the Value of Digital Credentials 2023-11-25 1EdTech

Founding members of the coalition include representatives from Anthology, Bowdoin College, The California State University System, Cengage, Greenville County Schools, Google, Instructure, University of Maryland Global Campus, Oracle, Southern New Hampshire University, Udemy, VitalSource, Western Governors University and Wichita State University.

To make Trusted Web concepts and information easier to look for and read A new website has been established

Development [GitHub] walt-id/waltid-ssikit: All-In-One SSI infrastructure toolkit 2023-11-23

Please be informed that, beginning from December 2023, the SSI Kit will no longer receive new features. Furthermore, the SSI Kit is planned for discontinuation by the end of Q3 2024.

However, all functionalities currently offered by the SSI Kit will be integrated into our new libraries, APIs, and apps under The Community Stack. This is aimed at providing a more modular, flexible, and efficient solution for your needs while ensuring familiar interfaces for a smooth transition.

Guest Blog: DIDComm Demo 2023-11-21 Decentralizd Identity Foundation

The DIDComm Demo allows you to connect to another person, a computer, a phone or simply another window in a different browser tab so you can see DIDComm messages traverse back and forth after the messages have been decrypted [...] to see how DIDComm works without needing to sift through or learn a substantial stack like Hyperledger Aries Cloud Agent Python (ACA-Py).

Sad but True

If you want to release your software as open source, release the bit (or a bit) that doesn‚Äôt have intrinsic business value. Use that value to pay for the rest

Company News SEDIMARK TO Leverage IOTA Tangle For Self Sovereign Identity 2023-11-22 CryptoNewsFlash

Full decentralized data Marketplace SEDIMARK recently went live with its deployment on the IOTA Tangle Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT). As part of the development, SEDIMARK will be deploying its own custom SSI framework. This move is set to revolutionize digital identity management within the marketplace.

Never would I have thought I‚Äôd use the word ‚Äòbeautiful‚Äô to describe my experience passing through immigration when traveling internationally, but that‚Äôs exactly how it felt last week in Aruba. The reason? Aruba‚Äôs Happy One Pass (AHOP). 

eIDAS 2.0 with Lissi: Neosfer spin-off focusses on digital identity with European ID-Wallets 2023-11-11 Lissi

The path to the future is already lined with promising collaborations, including municipal use cases with the cities of Cologne, Leipzig and Dresden as well as various use cases with major banks such as Commerzbank AG and ING Deutschland. SSI is the Key to Claiming Ownership in an AI-Enabled World 2023-11-24 Phil Windley

The future beckons with the promise of AI, but it's our digital identity that will define our place in it.

how can @Origin_Trail help OpenAI with decentralized AI? Origin Trail

OriginTrail is dedicated to building a trusted knowledge infrastructure for artificial intelligence. This infrastructure ensures the origin of information, fights misinformation, and promotes data governance.

00:14 • 8 days ago

Tuesday, 28. November 2023

Spruce Systems

Webinar: A Look Inside California‚Äôs Mobile Driver‚Äôs License Program

Register for our upcoming webinar to learn how SpruceID helped bring the California Mobile Driver's License to life.

Curious about what it takes to bring digital transformation to a state DMV? For the past 18 months, SpruceID partnered with the State of California DMV to bring mobile driver‚Äôs licenses (mDLs) to California residents. Earlier this fall, the State of California DMV launched its program, which now allows California residents to download and use an mDL on their smartphone through the California DMV Wallet mobile app.

Now, we‚Äôre excited to announce an upcoming webinar that will give you a behind-the-scenes look at launching the program in our webinar: Getting Started with Digital ID: A Look Inside California‚Äôs Mobile Driver‚Äôs License Program on December 13th, 11:00 AM PT.

Who You‚Äôll Hear From

This session‚Äôs speakers include Ajay Gupta, Chief Digital Transformation Officer at the State of California DMV, and Wayne Chang, Founder and CEO at SpruceID. As leaders from both the technology side and the government side, Wayne and Ajay will discuss how their teams worked together to achieve success throughout this initiative.

Moderating the webinar will be Russ Nichols, Senior Fellow for the Center of Digital Government.

Key Takeaways

In today‚Äôs digital-first world, it‚Äôs become critical for people to verify their identity in a digital and secure way ‚Äî and governments are at the forefront of each state‚Äôs digital transformation. One way government organizations are living up to this task is by issuing citizens mDLs, cryptographically-signed digital identity credentials.

In this conversation, we will discuss:

How the California DMV is offering mobile driver's licenses and other digital credentials, such as car registrations, to its residents and best practices for success The importance of open-source development to enable myriad use cases across public and private sectors for verifiable digital identity The security and accessibility advantages of digitally verifiable credentials Register Now

Visit our registration page to learn more about the webinar, see full speaker bios, and save your spot. We look forward to seeing you there!

Register Now
21:46 • 8 days ago

SC Media - Identity and Access

Novel SSH-based private RSA key extraction technique detailed

Vulnerable SSH servers could be compromised to secure private RSA host keys through a new passive attack method that involves the observation of computational faults during the signing process that exposes the private keys, The Hacker News reports.

Forgerock Blog

What are the Critical Capabilities of Access Management in 2023?

Evaluate your access management (AM) strategy with guidance from Gartner Access management (AM) has become instrumental in fueling business growth while protecting against modern attacks. Today's economic environment makes AM even more critical, with enterprises seeking a converged access management solution that can address myriad use cases for multiple populations. But what capabilities shoul
Evaluate your access management (AM) strategy with guidance from Gartner

Access management (AM) has become instrumental in fueling business growth while protecting against modern attacks. Today's economic environment makes AM even more critical, with enterprises seeking a converged access management solution that can address myriad use cases for multiple populations. But what capabilities should you prioritize for your organization?

The 2023 Gartner¬Æ Critical Capabilities for Access Management report is a technical companion to the Gartner Magic Quadrant‚Ñ¢ for Access Management. While the Magic Quadrant provides an overview of a vendor including its market share, Critical Capabilities is purely a technical analysis of a vendor's products and services.

This year Gartner scored 11 vendors against four common use cases, including workforce access management, business-to-consumer access management (B2C), business-to-business access management (B2B), and application development.

We are delighted to announce that ForgeRock received the highest scores in two of these use cases, namely B2C and B2B customer access management.

11 critical capabilities to consider for your 2024 roadmap

In addition to the four use cases, Gartner outlines a set of critical capabilities essential for any organization's access management strategy:

Core Access Management User Authentication Authorization and Adaptive Access Portable Identity Integration Business to Business Business to Consumer Customization and Extensibility API Access Control Threat Reporting and ITDR Resilience Ease of Deployment ForgeRock understands your business to the core

Our commitment to simplifying complex user journeys can be a differentiator for your business. We support various delegated administration approaches for B2B capabilities, all orchestrated seamlessly through ForgeRock Intelligent Access.

Moreover, our comprehensive catalog of global and regional cloud identity provider connectors, integrations with government IDs, customizable consent flows, self-service social identity registration, and a marketplace featuring a wide array of identity verification providers and wallets make us a solid choice.

We give you ultimate control

Customizability and extensibility are paramount for large enterprises and their unique use cases. Our solutions offer the flexibility and power required for different deployment models, while our Intelligent Access orchestration (‚ÄúTrees‚Äù) and SDKs simplify integrations for developers. We also provide robust support for integrations with both our identity gateway and third-party API gateways.

Deploy identity your way

ForgeRock embraces flexibility when it comes to identity deployment. Whether you prefer a fully cloud-based approach, on-premises solution, or a hybrid environment for gradual migration, we've got you covered. Recognizing the challenges of migration from legacy solutions, we've introduced pre-configured accelerators to facilitate co-existence with, and migration from, Oracle Access Manager and Broadcom CA SiteMinder to the ForgeRock Identity Cloud.

Ultimate security without sacrifice

ForgeRock Autonomous Access employs a unique blend of AI, machine learning, and pattern recognition to detect threats at the identity perimeter. Notably, we've addressed the rising challenges in MFA with features such as MFA push authentication with context and push authentication with number matching, enhancing both security and user experience. ForgeRock also supports passwordless authentication capabilities through FIDO2 WebAuthn standards and passkeys within the ForgeRock Identity Cloud.

ForgeRock and Ping Identity: A Winning Combination

I'm thrilled to announce that Ping Identity received the highest scores in one use case and the second highest in the three other use cases in the Gartner Critical Capabilities for Access Management research. To us, this recognition underscores Ping Identity's excellence and deep understanding of the AM market. Read more on Ping's performance here.

The results of the Gartner research speak for themselves. And now, by uniting together as one company, we are able to offer customers greater choice and flexibility to address their unique use cases for all identity types. We're confident that with our strong product offerings reinforced by our years of experience, we can help you become better positioned to innovate your identity roadmap today and well into the future.

I invite you to download the Gartner Critical Capabilities report to gain deeper insights into access management capabilities and how you can elevate your IAM strategy.

*Ping Identity and ForgeRock were evaluated independently before the companies were combined on August 23, 2023.
